title: Disable All Types of Access Tokens for FIPS-enabled instance (MVC)
description:
### Release notes


### Problem to solve

As the administrator of an instance, I wish to disable the creation of Personal Access Tokens (PATs) as authentication for any resources within the namespace.

This is a ~"FedRAMP Milestone::RAR Requirement" .

### MVC

1. For any instance that is `Gitlab::FIPS.enabled?`, PATs, PrATs, and GATS are not able to be created
2. If PATs, PrATs, and GATS  already exist prior to turn this setting on, do nothing (Because this is ~FedRAMP only, this scenario should not exist to begin with. But if it does, ignore them)

#### Future Iterations (Personal Access Token focused):

1. Expand functionality so it's not limited to FIPS only instances
2. Ability to enable/disable PAT creation from UI
1. Ability to enable/disable PAT creation from Namespace level
1. If PAT creation is disabled, existing PATs are revoked - this would include the ~frontend work of making it very clear that this is a disruptive action


### Metrics

<!-- How are you going to track usage of this feature? Think about user behavior and their interaction with the product. What indicates someone is getting value from it?

Create tracking issue using the Snowplow event tracking template. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/.gitlab/issue_templates/Snowplow%20event%20tracking.md

-->

### Notes

Before this is released to customers outside of ~FedRAMP instances, thought needs to be put into what to do with existing PATs.

What happens in the scenario where they are allowed, then disallowed, then allowed again? Should all existing PATs be revoked/deleted? Should they live again once the setting is turned back on?

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

Add specs to cover following cases when PAT creation is disabled:


* Ensure PATs, PrATs, and GATS cannot be created via the API or the UI
* Admin's can also not create PATs, PrATs, and GATS  for other users via the API
* Amin's cannot create PATs, PrATs, and GATS  for other users via the UI when they impersonate them
* Any existing PATs, PrATs, and GATS will stop working

epic.title: Access Token Enhancements

title: RSpec: retrying only failures doesn't run any examples and Crystalball report is empty as a result
description:
Job [#2021655824](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/2021655824) failed for b59c66306048beabc4dc4f4509c5ae8b257fd98f:

Trying to debug with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/79329

```
$ update_tests_mapping
/builds/gitlab-org/gitlab/tooling/lib/tooling/test_map_generator.rb:17:in `block in parse': undefined method `each' for nil:NilClass (NoMethodError)
	from /builds/gitlab-org/gitlab/tooling/lib/tooling/test_map_generator.rb:13:in `each'
	from /builds/gitlab-org/gitlab/tooling/lib/tooling/test_map_generator.rb:13:in `parse'
	from scripts/generate-test-mapping:16:in `<main>'
```

Indeed, it seems some Crystalball files have no examples: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/2023373567

Ok, so it’s related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/team-tasks/-/issues/1148, we expect RSpec to rerun the failed examples but it seems to not run any (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/2023373426):

```
Run options: include {:last_run_status=>"failed"}
All examples were filtered out
Test environment set up in 4.730209124 seconds
Finished in 8.19 seconds (files took 4 minutes 16.7 seconds to load)
0 examples, 0 failures
and the Crystalball report gets no examples.
```

This can be reproduced with the following file in `spec/`
[rspec_last_run_results.txt](/uploads/f7805fb458e15eda132f7dfeecc326d0/rspec_last_run_results.txt) and by running the following:

```
bin/rspec -Ispec -rspec_helper --color --format documentation --format RspecJunitFormatter --out rspec/junit_rspec-retry.xml --only-failures
```

title: Enqueuer job: improve aborted migrations handling
description:
### :fire: Problem

The enqueuer will pick aborted migrations to retry them.

The challenge is that the ~backend need to choose which step to retry: `pre_import` or `import`. To take this decision, the analysis described a way: look at the recorded migration timestamps of the container image.

The problem is that those timestamps could be unsynced with what happend on the container registry side due to restarts, request timeouts or other.

Thus, those timestamps should be considered as unreliable.

### :fire_engine: Solution

Use this [endpoint](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/container-registry/-/blob/master/docs-gitlab/api.md#get-repository-import-status) to get the real status of the migration and take the proper action out of the result of that call.

epic.title: Drive the Container Registry migration Phase 2 from Rails

title: Rate limits don't consider relative URL root if set
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

When GitLab is configured to use a [relative URL prefix](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/install/relative_url.html), our rate limits don't work correctly because they don't take the prefix into account when checking the request paths (e.g. the API rate limits look for a path starting with `/api`).

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

1. Set up a relative URL prefix as described on https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/install/relative_url.html.
   - In GDK you need to set this in `gdk.yml` and run `gdk reconfigure`.
   - The prefix needs to starts with a slash (e.g. `/your/prefix`).
   - Make sure you restart GitLab to apply this change.
1. Configure unauthenticated rate limits for web and API traffic, with a low threshold so you can trigger them easily.
   - This can be done in the admin UI, see https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/admin_area/settings/user_and_ip_rate_limits.html.
1. Send unauthenticated requests to an API path (e.g. `/your/prefix/api/v4/groups`) until you get a 429 response.
1. Check the `Ratelimit-Name` header in the response, it says `throttle_unauthenticated_web` rather than `throttle_unauthenticated_api`.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

Requests aren't correctly recognized, e.g. API traffic is counted as web traffic.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

Requests should still be correctly recognized.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

<!-- Paste any relevant logs - please use code blocks (```) to format console output, logs, and code
 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

### Possible fixes

<!-- If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem. -->

The path checks in `lib/gitlab/rack_attack/request.rb` also need to consider the relative URL root, like we do in e.g. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/0105bc151c52ecd83f10e4686a4265d729f57994/lib/gitlab/auth/auth_finders.rb#L334.

title: Remove `max_package_files_for_package_destruction` in application settings if it exists
description:
### :fire: Problem

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security/gitlab/-/merge_requests/2111, we added a new setting in the application settings: `max_package_files_for_package_destruction`.

That setting is not used from %"14.7" and up

### :fire_engine: Solution

Remove the column if it exists

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `admin_application_settings_service_usage_data_center`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [Service Usage Data Center](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/product-intelligence/-/issues/501) on production,
that is currently behind the `admin_application_settings_service_usage_data_center` feature flag.

We're creating a separate page so users be able to review, redact and submit usage ping.

## Owners

- Team: Product Intelligence
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_product_intelligence`
- Best individual to reach out to: @nbelokolodov 
- PM: @amandarueda 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

A new page named "Service Usage Data" will be available from Admin menu. The page will have Preview Payload UI blocked moved from the Metric and profiling page

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->
When the feature flag is enabled. The fix does not have any other dependency.
<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

We dont any any new functionality with this FF, so only the newly added page might be broken.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab-foss <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [x] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-default-enabling-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: External Status Checks: Expand documentation to include more detail
description:
### Problem to solve

Recently some questions were raised about the [External Status Checks feature](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/status_checks.html) in [Slack#g_manage_compliance](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CN7C8029H/p1643218310118000), and we noticed that not all the answers were fully documented.

### Proposal

Add documentation for:

- Which users have permission to "update" (respond to) an external status check.
- The [upcoming requirement](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/338827) for a `status` parameter in the [status check response payload](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/status_checks.html#set-status-of-an-external-status-check) including all the accepted values for that parameter and whether or not a failure status value is supported.
- The disconnect between "status check request" from GitLab to the external service and the "status check request" from the external service back to GitLab.  Unlike a typical request/response cycle, this one is completed in two separate asynchronous requests to allow the external service as much time as it needs to evaluate the result of the status check.

title: [MR Widget Eng] Test summary details
description:
### Overview 
This issue is to track the engineering efforts of the Test summary widget using the new [Merge request reports framework](https://design.gitlab.com/regions/merge-request-reports) and 2 of 2 Test Summary implementation issues. 

![Test_summary](/uploads/7c74e08839e15b05ed02bbbfb1821924/Test_summary.png)

### Resources
- [Related UX Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/336173)
- [Figma Design Specifications](https://www.figma.com/file/qEddyqCrI7kPSBjGmwkZzQ/Component-library?node-id=40575%3A46838)
- [Merge request reports framework](https://design.gitlab.com/regions/merge-request-reports)

### Proposal

**Add details and modal to the widget** (weight 2):

* render the list of failed/fixed tests at level three, including the recent failures text
  * i.e. `New: ProjectAccessToken validations requires the presence of a personal access token`
* convert/import the modal component, make each test's name a link that fills its data into the modal and opens the modal
* add the recent failures text at level one (this could be done in the first iteration if we decide that's easier during implementation)

title: Prune ProjectExportJob records
description:
Right now we have millions of `ProjectExportJob` rows in the database. Most of them aren't needed.

We should be able to remove them if:

1. They are older than a week.
1. If there is a newer entry per project.

`StuckExportJobsWorker` already does some cleaning of the status, but maybe we want a new Sidekiq worker to do the pruning.

We could also consider moving this data out into Redis so that it's expired automatically.

Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/102659

epic.title: Project Import/Export Technical Improvements

title: Make HAML scrollable tabs consistent with GitLab UI scrollable tabs
description:
Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/345699

Currently scrolling tabs are implemented in the [GitLab UI `GlTabs` component](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/base-tabs-tabs--with-scroll) and in HAML using [app/assets/javascripts/layout_nav.js#L38](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/layout_nav.js#L38). However, these two implementations function differently:

### GitLab UI `GlTabs` component

- Left and right arrows that are clickable.
- Can't scroll left and right, must click the arrows.

### HAML version 

- Left and right arrows that are not clickable. They are only used to indicate that there are more tabs.
- Must scroll left and right to see hidden tabs.

title: Refactor Complex Query Metric - issues_created_from_alerts
description:
For 

- "issues_created_from_alerts" [source code](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L838)

```sql
    "issues_created_from_alerts": "SELECT (SELECT COUNT(\"issues\".\"id\") FROM \"issues\" INNER JOIN \"alert_management_alerts\" ON \"alert_management_alerts\".\"issue_id\" = \"issues\".\"id\") + (SELECT COUNT(\"issues\".\"id\") FROM \"issues\" INNER JOIN \"issues_self_managed_prometheus_alert_events\" ON \"issues_self_managed_prometheus_alert_events\".\"issue_id\" = \"issues\".\"id\") + (SELECT COUNT(\"issues\".\"id\") FROM \"issues\" INNER JOIN \"issues_prometheus_alert_events\" ON \"issues_prometheus_alert_events\".\"issue_id\" = \"issues\".\"id\")",
```


1. Refactor to Make the logic simple, to only use `count` or `distinct_count` 
1. Overwrite `to_sql` if required, with the correct query for DWH
1. The logic for the query generate for DWH should be the same, we should be able to get in the end the same values

Related to #349858.

title: Migrate all UsageData usage to the new ServicePingMetrics class
description:
Related to #346640. Conversation https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/77629#note_820078043

As we migrate to instrumental classes for UsageData generations we created a dedicated `ServicePingMetrics` class.

The next step is to migrate all direct calls to `UsageData` and use the new class instead.

Important thing to consider is forced cash refresh (`force_refresh: true`) call. It has to be addressed in the current MR.

title: Backend: Improve the error messaging when fetching remote includes are timing out
description:
### Summary

Some users have been receiving a timeout error when using remote `include`s. In an effort to help the user understand when remote include references are timing out, this issue is to improve the error messaging that is displayed when this scenario occurs.

![image](/uploads/20d3cdd024f81f8bac5d56524f14fb76/image.png)

### Solution

By returning an appropriate error messaging when remote include references are timing out, it will enhance the user experience so that the user understands what is happening and can take appropriate actions.

~backend will change the message in `yaml_errors` to be `Request timed out when fetching configuration files.` (still weight 1)  
~frontend will update the actual UI component, which includes the title --> (Can be done by ~backend in the same MR since this is a `haml` update).

New error text should be:

> **Unable to create pipeline**
> 
> Request timed out when fetching configuration files.

We will remove the link to CI Lint from the error since it doesn't provide additional context about the error.

### Implementation
| Work Type | Description | Issue link |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |

title: Fix cross database transaction in Projects::OverwriteProjectService#execute
description:
Related to #340256.

## Problem

There is at least one case where we do `Project.transaction { Projects::DestroyService(...).execute }`. This is done in `Projects::OverwriteProjectService#execute` which does `Project.transaction` and then `#destroy_old_project` and then mentioned service. This service appears to be used by `import-export` feature. So, maybe they are the best team to solve this. This might also indicate that maybe we should keep this closed and create a new one. Do it at your discretion :)

We need to somehow fix `Projects::OverwriteProjectService#execute` to do it differently. To explicitly indicate this problem and place that needs to be considered the MR was created: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/78079. By removing `allow_cross_database_modification_within_transaction` the buggy behavior will be triggered.

For now, I re-open this issue since this the most comprehensive description of the solution.

> Note: This was discovered now since the `./spec/services/projects/overwrite_project_service_spec.rb` was part of `spec/support/database/cross-database-modification-allowlist.yml` and was not removed once the original issue was merged.

## Analysis

Based on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/340256#note_820203511

@lmcandrew This is a tricky topic that is likely to involve product. First of all, project import with overwrite basically replaces existing project with a completely new one, while preserving the same name & path (and a few other things like user stars). One might achieve the same outcome by manually deleting old project and importing a new one under the same name. What is the expected behaviour of such failed import?

I am guessing the main concern for using outermost `Project.transaction` during 'overwriting' process is to prevent potential data loss of the project that is being overridden, if something goes wrong. This service was introduced 4 years ago and didn't change much since. Does `Projects::DestroyService` guarantee against data loss if it fails to execute? I see there is `Projects::DestroyService#attempt_rollback` but it sounds like rollback is not guaranteed? Can there be a situation, where user initiated project import with overwrite fails because of destroy service failing, resulting in original project not being in it's original condition? Is this an acceptable potential outcome of a failed import attempt?

If destroy rollback preserves data then I think it should be possible to update it and not utilize the outer most `Project.transaction`, which should solve the issue of cross-DB transaction. If it doesn't - is partial data loss of the old project acceptable? Since project overwrite deletes the old project, does it matter which state the project is in if project destroy fails?

Currently the 'overwriting' process is:

1. Update a set of relations' `project_id` from old to new (stars, members, group links, etc)
1. Destroy old project
1. Rename new project to old project's name/path

I am proposing we update this process to start copying mentioned relation instead of updating/moving existing ones:

* If something goes wrong during the copying process, the old project is still intact and we do not need to update/move it's relations back. This does mean updating all of the services listed in [Projects::OverwriteProjectService#move_before_destroy_relationships](http://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/89a365dd2f50a258573d5d51907b184e8ffacb4c/app/services/projects/overwrite_project_service.rb#L54-L59)
* If something goes wrong during old project removal, old project is also intact, we just need to clean up/remove new project

side note: I don't fully understand right now by just looking at the code what happens with new project when old one is failed to be deleted/renamed (it might be removed elsewhere). We attempt to [restore the repository](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/89a365dd2f50a258573d5d51907b184e8ffacb4c/app/services/projects/overwrite_project_service.rb#L77-L77), but what about all other data? Can data loss potentially happen already?

Additionally, we [log any exceptions of this service](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/89a365dd2f50a258573d5d51907b184e8ffacb4c/app/services/projects/overwrite_project_service.rb#L44) but I haven't seen any occurrences of this in the past 7 days on production (that's how far our logs go).


### Solution

In terms of the solution, I think we should:

1. Update all the relation 'move' services to perform a copy instead
1. Update `Projects::OverwriteProjectService#destroy_old_project` to not be in `Project.transaction`
1. If something goes wrong during old project destroy - remove previously copied relations, to match existing behaviour
1. If something goes wrong during new project rename - remove previously copied relations, to match existing behaviour

:five: for the estimation.

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `publish_project_deleted_event`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the fix for namespace statistics refresh](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/342049) on production,
that is currently behind the `publish_project_deleted_event` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::testing" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_testing`
- Best individual to reach out to: @alberts-gitlab 
- PM: @jreporter 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

When a project is deleted, the namespace's usage statistics is immediately updated. The statistics should no longer include the usage by the project that has been deleted.

### When is the feature viable?

1. When the feature flag is enabled. The fix does not have any other dependency.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

There would be increased activity in [recalculating Namespace::RootStorageStatistics](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/342049-update-namespace-stats-when-project-deleted/app/models/namespace/root_storage_statistics.rb#L26-28). If this affects availability, the feature flag can be turned off.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab-foss <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [x] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-default-enabling-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Geo Sites - Console error dump when Site card is collapsed
description:
## What/Why

~"found:staging.gitlab.com" 

There seems to be an issue with the `GlPopover` in [geo_node_verification_info.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/geo_nodes/components/details/primary_node/geo_node_verification_info.vue#L52-59).  When you collapse a Site card it will dump an error to the console about not being able to find the `$el`.

## Steps to reproduce

1. Go to the Geo Sites Dashboard
2. Open your dev console
3. Collapse a Site Card
4. Note the console.error

## Screenshots

<details>
<summary>console.error from Staging</summary>
![Staging](/uploads/675813ea77c0af7917491f2fa09e5e79/Staging.png)

</details>

<details>
<summary>console.error from GDK</summary>

![GDK](/uploads/07aba5f1d2be92f6ab12480279515839/GDK.png)

</details>

## What do we do

When you collapse the component the popover is still trying to keep itself mounted but loses the element it is listening to behind a `v-if`.  There is likely a better way to find our target element that won't break when it is hidden.  This doesn't cause the popover to stop working as when you uncollapse the site card it will continue to show up.  Also noting we have other `GlPopover` usages in this scope that aren't erroring.  This could be a good place to look for if we are doing something wrong/different on this one.

**note:** Since this is only a console error and not a UI issue it hasn't been reported and been around for nearly a year.  This is a low priority but would be nice to fix to not cause any "red herrings" for our support engineers if they end up debugging a real UI problem.

title: Matchers must provide a value so that uniqueness can be determined
description:
### Proposal

Propose that DAST browser-based matchers always provide a value on successful match. This will help ensure that uniqueness can be determined when evaluating results of a vulnerability check. This is achieved by using explicit bindings to variables defined in a uniqueness definition template.

An error should be thrown in the event that a variable declared in the uniqueness template has no definition. There should never be a need to call the `Matches` method more than once on a matcher.

### Example

For the following uniqueness template, the variable `cookie_name` is defined. The value for `cookie_name` would be the result of all values populated by a matcher with the `CookieName` placeholder.

YAML:
```yaml
report_uniqueness:
    template: "missing-http-only{cookie_name}"
```

Matcher:
```go
func (matcher *CookieAttributeMatcher) Matches(_ *browserk.HTTPRequest, _ *browserk.HTTPResponse, cookies []*browserk.Cookie) *MatchResult {
    ...
    return Matched(browserk.PlaceholderCookieName, cookie.Name)
}
```

## Potential Issues

#### Multiple values for the same name

In the event that there are two `Cookie` `Matchers` used, both which match, then there will be multiple values with different names. Suggested solution is to use a concatenation of all values.

For example, it is plausible that both cookie matchers could match:

```yaml
match:
  type: "or-condition"
  conditions:
    - type: "match"
      location: "cookie_name"
      expression: "session_id"
    - type: "match"
      location: "cookie_attribute"
      expression: "[hH]ttp[oO]nly"
```

#### Matchers that exit early on success will not populate all values

The [OrMatcher](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/blob/c2154144d142190387229f21c111634301295046/scanner/plugin/vulnerabilities/http_message_matcher/or_matcher.go#L22) returns `true/Matched` as soon as it processes a matcher that is matched. This will need to change to always execute all matchers, else some matched values will not be populated for those matchers.

```go
for _, matcher := range or.matchers {
    if result := matcher.Matches(request, response, cookies); result.Match {
        return Matched(result.MatchedValues...)
    }
}
```

Similarly, the [ResponseHeaderValueMatcher](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/blob/main/scanner/plugin/vulnerabilities/http_message_matcher/response_header_value_matcher.go) will need to process all headers, instead of returning on the first successfully matched header. Headers can be returned in different orders from servers/the browser, hence this could lead to non-deterministic results if we use the header name/value in the uniqueness template.

```go
if matched, _ := matcher.matchesValue(val); matched {
    return Matched(val)
}
```

There are other matchers with similar problems.

#### What value should each matcher save?

Currently, the `CookieAttributeMatcher` saves the entire cookie value. Should this save `cookie_name`, `cookie_value`, or `cookie`? Or should it save values for all three?

For example, the `16.4` check uses `response_header_value` in the template but checks for `response_header_name`.
```yaml
report_uniqueness:
  template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}{response_header_value}x-backend-server"
match:
  type: "match"
  location: "response_header_name"
  expression: "[xX]-[bB]ackend-[sServer]"
```

#### Values from matched results vs values from requests/responses

It is plausible that a uniqueness template could have a value like `{request_method}`. Request method could be obtained directly from the `HTTPRequest`, or it could be obtained from the result of a `RequestValueMatcher`. Suggest that we first look for the result from the matcher, and then look in the request.

That way the `{request_method}` value in the template could be used even when the `RequestValueMatcher` is not used as a matcher. Maybe this isn't necessary, this decision can always be made later when more information may provide more clarity on the best approach.

## An alternative approach

It could be that named matchers are more useful, for example:

```yaml
report_uniqueness:
  template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}{backend_server_header}x-backend-server"
match:
  name: "backend_server_header"
  type: "match"
  location: "response_header_name"
  expression: "[xX]-[bB]ackend-[sServer]"
```

However, when adding named variable to the match result, it still isn't clear whether the header name, value or both should be added as the value. It might be prudent to add something like `{backend_server_header:name}` as the template variable.

## Implementation plan

We're moving ahead with the alternative approach. This issue can be considered complete when we've worked out uniqueness template for all checks.

- [x] 16.1
  - `template: "{request_path}missing-content-type"`
- [x] 16.2
  - `template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}{response_header_value}"`
  - Requires `ResponseHeadersMatcher` to have a headers matched value, and to use `response_header:value`
- [x] 16.3
  - `template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}{response_header_value}"`
  - Requires `ResponseHeadersMatcher` to have a headers matched value, and to use `response_header:value`
- [x] 16.4
  - `template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}{response_header_value}x-backend-server"`
  - Requires `ResponseHeadersMatcher` to have a headers matched value, and to use `response_header:value`
- [x] 16.5
  - `template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}{response_header_value}x-aspnet-version"`
  - Requires `ResponseHeadersMatcher` to have a headers matched value, and to use `response_header:value`
- [x] 16.6
  - `template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}{response_header_value}x-aspnetmvc-version"`
  - Requires `ResponseHeadersMatcher` to have a headers matched value, and to use `response_header:value`
- [x] 16.7
  - `template: "{request_path}hsts"`
- [x] 200.1
  - `template: "{request_path}{private_ip_address}sensitive-information"`
- [x] 352.1
  - `template: "{request_path}absence-anti-csrf"`
- [x] 548.1
  - `template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}directory-indexing"`
- [x] 601.1
  - `template: "{request_path}redirection"`
- [x] 614.1
  - `template: "missing-http-only{cookie_name}"`
  - Template looks incorrect, references `missing-http-only`
  - Requires a check to be able to create multiple findings, if there is multiple unique keys
  - `AuthenticationCookieAttributeMatcher` will have to add all matching and not matching cookies
  - `NotMatcher` will have to do something sensible matched values so they can be found
- [x] 693.1
  - `template: "{request_path_excluding_last_segment}missing-x-content-type-options"`
- [x] 829.1
  - `template: "{request_path}untrusted-control-sphere"`
- [x] 829.2
  - `template: "{request_path}invalid-sub-resource-integrity"`
- [x] 1004.1
  - `template: "missing-http-only{cookie_name}"`
  - Requires a check to be able to create multiple findings, if there is multiple unique keys
  - `AuthenticationCookieAttributeMatcher` will have to add all matching and not matching cookies
  - `NotMatcher` will have to do something sensible matched values so they can be found

title: Research streamlining or eliminating setup-test-env
description:
### Research prompt

Can the `gitaly`, `shell`, and `workhorse` setup and configure jobs in `setup-test-env` retrieve built components from a [generic package registry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/generic_packages/index.html#publish-a-generic-package-by-using-cicd) or another storage platform (like GitLab releases, GCS) that get built in the project?

This can help reduce the frequency of software builds across CI and local GitLab Development with the GDK.



### Potential benefits

- Reproducible process of building and publishing binaries/packages that can leverage CI
- Align builds for local, CI, Cloud development 
- Make pre-built `gitaly`, `shell` and `workhorse` available for all development environments through retrieval instead of building

title: Restrict notes confidentiality to comments
description:
The option to make notes confidential should be limited to the notes that are a comment or a reply to a comment.

### Proposal

Notes don't have a clear way to distinguish their type, despite having the attribute `type` because it's allowed to be `NULL` when built. We could check for the presence of other attributes that are required for diff notes, but it might be unreliable. Perhaps an easier way to identify the note's type is needed.

title: Audit Events: OpenSSL::SSL::SSLError exceptions caused by streaming endpoints
description:
## Problem to solve

In the past 24 hours there have been a handful of [`OpenSSL::SSL::SSLError` exceptions](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/3158270/?environment=gprd) reported in context of the Sidekiq worker called `AuditEvents::AuditEventStreamingWorker`.  This is likely being caused because a user has configured an [Audit Event streaming](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/audit_event_streaming.html) endpoint that does not have SSL correctly enabled.  The consequence is that events are not being streamed to the user-configured endpoint.

## Proposal

`AuditEvents::AuditEventStreamingWorker` should rescue `OpenSSL::SSL::SSLError` exceptions, because GitLab does not have control over an endpoint's SSL configuration.

### Also considered

- Disable the endpoint. This seems like overkill, because SSL configuration errors are often temporary, and it is not clear that these requests require SSL authentication anyway.
- Fall back to HTTP. "If the user's defined endpoint isn't available, we shouldn't pick a less secure alternative for them."

title: Figure out a removal flow for security report schemas
description:
## Problem

After we deprecate a schema, at some point we must remove it. It appears we can just delete the schema file from the repository and be done with it but perhaps a cop as suggested in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350993#implementation-plan would prevent accidental removals of deprecated-but-still-supported or supported schemas.

## Implementation plan

1.  ~backend Create a spec that verifies that all supported and deprecated schema versions are present on the disk

epic.title: Enforce validation of security reports

title: [Feature flag] Enable rejection of security reports with invalid or deprecated schemas
description:
## Summary

This issue is to rollout [validation enforcement of security reports](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6968) on production, that is currently behind the `enforce_security_report_validation` feature flag.

## Owners

- Team: Secure – Threat Insights
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_secure_threat_insights`
- Best individual to reach out to: `@Jonathan Schafer` (@jschafer) or `@Michał Zając` (@Quintasan)
- PM: Thiago Figueiró `@thiagocsf`

## Stakeholders

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

1. Decreased CPU and memory usage due to invalid reports not being ingested
2. Decreased number of invalid vulnerabilities making it to the database

### When is the feature viable?

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

1. New pipelines will not create vulnerabilities if the report doesn't pass the validation, since the artifacts remain for some time there should be no data loss if we quickly disable the feature flag

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [ ] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set enforce_security_report_validation true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set enforce_security_report_validation true --staging`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab enforce_security_report_validation true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab-foss enforce_security_report_validation true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com enforce_security_report_validation true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org enforce_security_report_validation true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-com enforce_security_report_validation true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> enforce_security_report_validation true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set enforce_security_report_validation <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set enforce_security_report_validation <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set enforce_security_report_validation true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-default-enabling-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `enforce_security_report_validation`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set enforce_security_report_validation false
```

title: Deprecate use of members API for invite modal in favor of invitations API
description:
## Problem

Currently when inviting someone to be a member in the invite modal, we make 2 calls to the API

1. `/members` with invites that are to current users.
1. `/invitations` with invites that are to emails(not current users).

Each endpoint responds differently when encountering an error.

This causes downstream issues in response codes and how errors are handled in the response. 
- `invitations` endpoint provides a json object with each `email` being a key in a hash.
- `members` endpoint provides a json object with each `user` being an element of an array.

This isn't sustainable and will only cause more issues when trying to deal with errors in the display and also extending.

## Solution

- [x] Ensure the error responses and status codes are the same when submitting emails or users from the invite modal.
   - extend the `/invitations` API to handle both `users` and `emails`, deprecating the use of `/members` from the invite modal.
   - see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/353008 in case we deprecate a parameter here.
   - resolve with !80733
- [x] Remove the specific parsing of the `members` API from the [invite modal error parser](http://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/cf9fc53c2aa232460fa7a8f79c8a73df37154876/app/assets/javascripts/invite_members/utils/response_message_parser.js#L20-20)
   - this will need to be a separate MR from the one above due to possible mixed deployments where FE and BE code can be out of sync.
   - resolve with !80733
- [x] Improve messaging when attempting to lower an inherited user's access level - see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/247208#note_843335734
   - resolve with !80733
- [x] Allow inherited users to be re-invited at a higher role than their current inherited role - will resolve https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/247208#note_835103747 
   - resolve with !80733
- [x] Investigate the possibility of combining the invites from the invite modal into one submission to the `/invitations` API.
   - if it does seem achievable, open a new issue to implement as the final step of completing this issue.
   - resolve with !80733

title: Implement a security report schema deprecation mechanism
description:
## Why are we doing this work?

In order to enforce validation of security report schemas we need a mechanism to specify which versions are supported and which ones are deprecated.

## Implementation plan

1. Extend `lib/gitlab/ci/parsers/security/validators/schema_validator.rb` with `SUPPORTED_VERSIONS` and `DEPRECATED_VERSIONS` hashes

```ruby
SUPPORTED_VERSIONS = {
  sast: %w[14.0.0 14.1.0],
  dast: %w[13.0.0 14.0.0],
  ...
}

DEPRECATED_VERSIONS = {
  sast: %w[13.0.0 13.1.0]
  dast: %w[12.9.0 12.10.0]
  ...
}
```

2. Extend specs to check for the file presence on disk and that the versions declared match the ones that are supported/deprecated

## Things to consider if the implementation plan doesn't scale well enough

In the scenario when we have a big number of schemas to deprecate and support we might have to consider a different approach on how to maintain the list of schemas:

1. Split the schema files into `deprecated/*.json` and `supported/*.json` and have the model automatically populate the values
1. Create a Rake task to generate the constants (similar to GraphQL docs)
1. Resolve dependency versions using (in)equality operators

## Testing

- Ensure the spec contains validations for supported version, deprecated version and unsupported version for each analyser type
- Ensure MR is reviewed by counterpart SET

title: Push iteration_cadences frontend FF for direct descendant groups
description:
An iteration cadence could be created for a parent group but would be unavailable for a descendant group. For example, a cadence and iterations could be scoped to `gitlab-org` but the team that use the cadence could work under a subgroup like `gitlab-org/plan-stage`. Because we only push `:iteration_cadences` FF for a group if the group has the FF directly enabled, the group's subgroup cannot use the cadence related features on the frontend.

Discovered the issue in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/77755#note_807007597.

Suggested fix:

- Check if a group's ancestors have `:iteration_cadences` FF enabled and push the FF to the frontend accordingly.
- Cache the above result for performance.

Steps to reproduce:

- in a group, create an iteration cadence.
- Then create a subgroup.
- Inside that subgroup, create a project.
- In the project, create an issue.
- Assign the issue to an iteration in the cadence you created.
- You’ll see in the iteration dropdown in the issue sidebar that the iterations are not grouped by their cadence name.
- This is because the FF is not enabled for the Project or the immediate project’s ancestor subgroup

title: Clarify if an MR widget contains items when no issues are detected
description:
## Description

The following discussion from !78138 should be addressed:

- [ ] @mfluharty started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/78138#note_817186385):  (+1 comment)

    > **observation(non-blocking,out-of-scope):** I find it confusing that the expand button is visible and clickable when there are no issues to show:
    > 
    > ![Screen_Recording_2022-01-20_at_13.39.33](/uploads/90f988d07b45417bc74859afc2ffe15d/Screen_Recording_2022-01-20_at_13.39.33.mov)

## Proposal

Remove the expansion button if there are no accessibility issues found. See the UI specs in [Figma](https://www.figma.com/file/qEddyqCrI7kPSBjGmwkZzQ/Component-library?node-id=40555%3A46295).

We will also need this support for:
- [code quality widget](https://www.figma.com/file/qEddyqCrI7kPSBjGmwkZzQ/Component-library?node-id=40483%3A44585)
- [license compliance widget](https://www.figma.com/file/qEddyqCrI7kPSBjGmwkZzQ/Component-library?node-id=40586%3A57652)

### Implementation details
Implementation-wise, I think we just need to adjust the `v-if` condition(s) of [the collapse button in the widget ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/components/extensions/base.vue#L243-258)`base.vue` component so that when there is no additional content to show in the expanded state, we don't show the expand button. That way it'll be built into the framework and apply to all of the widgets.

title: Add ability to filter on authentication token type to Registry logs
description:
### Problem

We need to be able to determine how much registry transfer originates from Runners, and how much originates from other sources. This will help us answer https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com-top-initiatives/free-saas/-/issues/52 (internal only).

### Solution

The only way to accomplish this in the short/mid-term is to infer the type of client through the type of authentication used for the container registry. **It's important to note that this won't apply to unauthenticated requests (when downloading public images without a preceding login), but this is the best we can do for now.**

Given that authentication for the registry is provided by GitLab Rails, a solution requires the following steps:

1. **Rails:** When receiving an authentication request for the container registry (`/jwt/auth` endpoint):

   1. Determine the type of auth credentials provided in the request. For the container registry, the relevant types of auth are CI/build tokens (runners), PAT, deploy tokens, and GitLab/LDAP credentials.

   1. Based on the above information, when emitting the corresponding JWT token, embed a metadata field within `meta` (a new JSON object that we can use to aggregate any metadata fields embedded in JWT tokens from now on) to identify the type of authentication. The key of this attribute should be `auth_type` and the value should be one of `build`, `ci`, `personal_access_token`, `deploy_token`, and `gitlab_or_ldap`.

      These values match the ones used internally in Rails, and can be read from the `type` attribute of the [`Gitlab::Auth::Result`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d5227355ad4f67418c1d706bb4b46383b073f772/lib/gitlab/auth/result.rb#L11) instance. This instance is built within the [`JwtController`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d5227355ad4f67418c1d706bb4b46383b073f772/app/controllers/jwt_controller.rb#L34). It should be noted that when calling the `Auth::ContainerRegistryAuthenticationService` in the `JwtController` ([here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d5227355ad4f67418c1d706bb4b46383b073f772/app/controllers/jwt_controller.rb#L22)), we currently only pass the `project` and `authentication_abilities` properties of the `Gitlab::Auth::Result` instance, we don't pass the instance itself (or the `type` attribute). So this must change in order to read (or receive) the `type` of authentication in `Auth::ContainerRegistryAuthenticationService` (where JWT tokens are generated).

1. **Container Registry:** For every inbound request with a valid authentication token:
   1. Parse the `meta.auth_type` attribute within the JWT token (if any);
   1. Inject the auth type key/value pair in the request-scoped context;
   1. Log the auth type in all request-scoped log entries. The `blob downloaded` and `new blob uploaded` log entries are the more important ones for the purpose of this issue, but it doesn't hurt to include it in all log entries.

title: Advanced Search: Collect code search snippets and expected hits
description:
### Overview 

It's important to establish testing first in resolving occurrences that are related to characters and searches that aren't working. Many times a change that will fix one use case will create additional issues and there needs to be a way to test against variable solutions to resolve. 


I propose to use this issue to continue the discussion in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350396#note_814694593 and as a placeholder for code search test examples.

This issue is Blocking https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346914

### Steps

- Create a list of Test Snippets and hits
- Create a test for the known snippets and hits in the list below. 



## Code snippets for the test suite (WIP)

Examples we've seen recently from our customers:

| Code snippet | Search term(s) for expected hit |
| ------ | ------ |
| `https://s3.amazonaws.com/foo/bar/baz.png` | `foo/bar` |
| `id("foo.bar-baz-conventions")` | `bar-baz-conventions`, `baz`, `baz-conventions` | 
| `extends: .gitlab-tests-image` | `gitlab-tests-image`, `tests-image`, `gitlab-tests` |
| `We [plan ambitiously](#ambitious-planning).` | `#ambitious-planning`, `ambitious-planning` |
| `https://test.or.dev.com/repository/maven-all` | `https://test.or.dev.com/repository/maven-all`,`https://test.or.dev.com/repository`, `test.or.dev.com/repository/maven-all`, `repository/maven-all`| 
| `q = "SET @@session.sql_log_bin=0;"` | `sql_log_bin`, `sql_log_bin=0` | 
| `uri: "v3/delData",` | `v3/delData` |
| | |

Please feel free to add more examples

/cc @john-mason @ebanks @changzhengliu @JohnMcGuire
