description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [romap settings](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/345158/) on production,
that is currently behind the `roadmap_settings` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Product planning (Plan)
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_product_planning`
- Best individual to reach out to: @fguibert 
- PM: @cdybenko 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab-foss <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-default-enabling-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

description:

16 projects

- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025215
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/brakeman | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025397
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025447
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/flawfinder | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025769
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025796
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kics | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025837
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/kubesec | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025873
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/mobsf | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_836540926
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025908
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/phpcs-security-audit | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_836531611
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/pmd-apex | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025964
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/secrets | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835025995
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/security-code-scan | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835026024
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/semgrep | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835026039
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/sobelow | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835026073
- [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/spotbugs | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350814#note_835026097

## Plan

The go [report](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/report/) dependency is responsible for creating reports for our analyzers. [report@v2.0.0](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/report/-/blob/v2.0.0/version.go#L10-19) used schema version 3.0.0 while [report@v2.1.0](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/report/-/blob/v2.1.0/version.go#L10-19) uses schema version 14.0.0. Therefore, we need to double check the following for each project:

* Analyzer uses report dependency version 2.1.0 or newer.
* Analyzer uses the report dependency to create the report (it used to be the [common](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/) dep)

I will create a comment below for each analyzer as I check them off with a link to the comment in this description.

title: Frontend: Reduce the complexity of `handleMergeButtonClick`
description:
### What

Let's look at reducing the complexity and "bloat" of the `handleMergeButtonClick` method in the component https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/components/states/ready_to_merge.vue

### Why

Our UI/UX around mergability is getting more complex and in return this is leading to our code getting more complex. In particular the `handleMergeButtonClick` method. This method is doing a lot. It has a lot of state checks going on to determine if confirmation modals need to be shown and other conditionals etc. I think we should abstract some of these checks.

We also have other lower level components that call this method with different parameters which could lead to regressions. A spike might be useful here to come up with a few different proposals. 

### Proposal

I think a good first step to reducing the complexity would be instead of using a single merge button, we could use multiple merge buttons with an explicit method for each one. To keep the logic contained and less room for regressions.

#### Proposal updates

- **2022-06-10:** The team [needs more time](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350804#note_985738899) to refine this and decompose it into smaller issues deployed behind a feature flag and will do that during %"15.2". One of those issues (empty feature flag?) may be pulled back into the %"15.2" milestone to move this forward.

title: Update usage of newly created gitlab-ui CSS utilities
description:
To quickly create [the trial registration reassurances experiment](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6300) and get it rolled out, we put some new CSS utility definitions right into the product rather than taking the time to add them to the `gitlab-ui` project.

Those utility classes have now been added to the `gitlab-ui` project, so as part of our cleanup efforts of the experiment, we need to remove our definitions of those same classes from the codebase as well as update them where the names may have changed slightly.

## Related `gitlab-ui` issues

- gitlab-org/gitlab-ui#1526+
- gitlab-org/gitlab-ui#1497+
- gitlab-org/gitlab-ui#1490+
- gitlab-org/gitlab-ui#1491+

epic.title: [Engineering] Experiment Cleanup: Add reassurance to the trial flow – Design 1

title: Frontend: API Security updates for DAST
description:
Main Issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/327070

## Why are we doing this work

In order to switch to DAST On-demand API scan, a few frontend changes need to be put in place. 

This [design issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/348725) details the changes.

* [:art:. Figma file](https://www.figma.com/file/o6NoqgLnxv0KnK2y9Qum51/DAST-Configuration-UI?node-id=1014%3A31065)
* [:desktop: Prototype](https://www.figma.com/proto/o6NoqgLnxv0KnK2y9Qum51/DAST-Configuration-UI?page-id=1014%3A30234&node-id=1014%3A44808&viewport=429%2C48%2C0.99&scaling=min-zoom&starting-point-node-id=1014%3A44808)

### Implementation Plan

This should affect all places rendering DAST Site Profile related information

#### Copy updates

- [x] Change "Rest API" to "API"
- [x] Change "Target URL" to "API Endpoint URL"
- [x] Change "Excluded URLS" to "Excluded Paths"

#### New option - "Scan Method"

- [x] Add a new `GlDropdown` component
  - [x] with label as `Scan method`
  - [x] with description as `Select which testing method to use`
  - [x] add [documentation link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dast_api/#enable-dast-api-scanning) to it
  - with options
     - `HTTP Archive (HAR)`
     - `OpenAPI`
     - `Postman collection`
- [x] Add corresponding input fields
  - [x] `HAR file path or URL`
  - [x] `OpenAPI Specification file path or URL`
  - [x] `Postman collection file path or URL`
- Reusing API fuzzing components (To be evaluated further)
  - [x] Create a new component and make it reusable
  - [x] or just reuse [`SCAN_MODES`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/6e204daf0ee57b4f9486f0c1a46a7b1f0040fced/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_configuration/api_fuzzing/constants.js)

#### Affected frontend components (for all the changes)

- [x] DAST Site Profile Form
   - [x] [`dast_site_profile_form.vue`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/5eebc6b3d86e3eab26ba96e0b606cca80bb85cee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_configuration/dast_profiles/dast_site_profiles/components/dast_site_profile_form.vue)
- [x] DAST Profile Summary
   - [x] [`site_profile_summary.vue` ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/7a17f2b11e3a8669e4f646ba12e1d2b1508f9ae7/ee/app/assets/javascripts/on_demand_scans_form/components/profile_selector/site_profile_summary.vue)
- [x] Corresponding Specs

#### GraphQL changes
See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/327070#graphql for details
- [x] Update `dast_site_profiles.query.graphql`
- [x] Update `dastSiteProfileCreate`
- [x] Update `dastSiteProfileUpdate`

#### Feature flag
- [x] Put all the changes behind [`dast_api_scanner`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/345837) feature flag

title: Common class for registry migration settings
description:
### :fire: Problem
The [container registry migration] has many toggles to control how the migration is done.

We have:
* many application settings
* many feature flags

Some feature flags need to be translated to actual values. 

For example, we have wait durations that are set by feature flags. If the fast mode feature flag is enabled, then the wait duration should be set to `0`.

### :fire_engine: Solution

Introduce a `ContainerRegistry::Migration` module and have class methods that will:
* alias feature flags/application settings
* "interpret" or "translate" feature flags/application settings.

epic.title: Drive the Container Registry migration Phase 2 from Rails

title: Stop raising errors in calculate reactive cache of Environment model
description:
In the Error budget [research issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/ci-cd/release-group/release/-/issues/93) for ~"group::release" we identified `ExternalServiceReactiveCachingWorker` is one of the [top Sidekiq errors](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/ci-cd/release-group/release/-/issues/93#note_805907622).

On further investigation we noticed that all these are Kubernetes pod/cluster unavailability/timeout errors as shown in the below screenshot.

![Screenshot_2022-01-20_at_5.24.56_PM](/uploads/f8781b49665d1c4cd23d09f42c17baa6/Screenshot_2022-01-20_at_5.24.56_PM.png)

Looks like we are not `rescue`ing these errors in the [`calculate_reactive_cache`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/environment.rb#L304) method in Enviornment model. In the `calculate_reactive_cache` we should capture the errors and should return gracefully with a nil or a value which is cacheable instead of throwing exceptions.


Log: https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/6fdc60d0-79e8-11ec-9dd2-93d354bef8e7

![Screenshot_2022-01-20_at_5.29.22_PM](/uploads/dcb73b82af8d0a8e3cb7e0390e1b4892/Screenshot_2022-01-20_at_5.29.22_PM.png)

epic.title: Release Stage Error Budget Improvements

title: [Feature flag] Enable projects pending deletion tab for all users
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346976) on production,
that is currently behind the `project_owners_list_project_pending_deletion` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->
It displays the "Pending deletion" tab to both users with administrator access and assigned the owner role with projects that have been deleted if the instance is using ~"GitLab Premium" or above.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::compliance" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_manage_compliance`
- Best individual to reach out to: @huzaifaiftikhar1
- PM: @sam.white

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->
Disable the feature flag `project_owners_list_project_pending_deletion`

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab-foss <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org <feature-flag-name> true`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [x] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status f9e06ba8d579e58f9a666f27bb713808649dec30`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [x] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [x] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [x] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [x] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [x] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set project_owners_list_project_pending_deletion false
```

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `pipeline_editor_include_file_links` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete pipeline_editor_include_file_links --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete pipeline_editor_include_file_links --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete pipeline_editor_include_file_links`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set pipeline_editor_include_file_links false
```

title: Frontend: Remember the open/closed state in local storage for `include:` file links
description:
This is a frontend issue for the original proposal based on the original [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7064).

## 🧩 Problem

Complex CI/CD configuration can contain multiple pipelines added to the main config using the `include` keyword. When editing or troubleshooting your config it's difficult to navigate between the `.gitlab-ci-yml` and the included files.

Additionally, a complex pipeline configuration might contain separate files for downstream pipelines and other files.

Engineers who author pipelines would like to edit all of their pipelines files in one place and take advantage of the pipeline editor features like pipeline visualization, linting, etc.

## Implementation

The breakdown for this feature is as follows:

| Work Type | Description | Issue Link |
| ------ | ------ |  ------ |
| ~backend | Expose includes link |  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/344937 |
| ~frontend  | Change the pipeline editor fixed layout to full-width | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346331 |
| ~frontend  | Introduce the feature flag and the empty drawer.** | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350721 |
| ~frontend  | Pass down the content to the drawer and format it properly | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350722  |
| ~frontend  | **Remember the open/closed state in local storage** | :point_left: You are here |
| ~frontend | Add feature discovery popover | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360111 |
| ~frontend  | Roll out feature flag | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/357219 |
| ~backend | Backend: Add toggle flag to UserCalloutFeatureNameEnum to allow for popover dismissal | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/365347 | 
| ~frontend | Store the pipeline editor popovers state in the database | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360635 |
| ~backend | Add messaging when files can't be fetched due to invalid CI configuration | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360431 |

The frontend implementation is explained in detail in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/344940#note_790001555.

Some implementation notes for this step:
1. Ensure that the opened/closed state of the file tree is remembered. It should be closed by default
1. Also save in local storage if the user has already dismissed the empty state notification.

> ![Screen_Recording_2022-03-31_at_11.01.00](/uploads/61e98365afa686be94460804f209704d/Screen_Recording_2022-03-31_at_11.01.00.mov)

title: Frontend: Pass down and format properly the content for `include:` file links
description:
This is a frontend issue for the original proposal based on the original [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7064).

### Release notes
Complex CI/CD configuration can contain multiple pipelines added to the main config using the `include` keyword. When editing or troubleshooting your config it's difficult to navigate between the `.gitlab-ci-yml` and the included files. In this release we've added to the pipeline editor, the ability to locate and view the file configuration which are been included in your pipeline.


### 🧩 Problem

Complex CI/CD configuration can contain multiple pipelines added to the main config using the `include` keyword. When editing or troubleshooting your config it's difficult to navigate between the `.gitlab-ci-yml` and the included files.

Additionally, a complex pipeline configuration might contain separate files for downstream pipelines and other files.

Engineers who author pipelines would like to edit all of their pipelines files in one place and take advantage of the pipeline editor features like pipeline visualization, linting, etc.

## Implementation

The breakdown for this feature is as follows:

| Work Type | Description | Issue Link |
| ------ | ------ |  ------ |
| ~backend | Expose includes link |  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/344937 |
| ~frontend  | Change the pipeline editor fixed layout to full-width | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346331 |
| ~frontend  | Introduce the feature flag and the empty drawer. | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350721 |
| ~frontend  | **Pass down the content to the drawer and format it properly** | :point_left: You are here  |
| ~frontend  | Remember the open/closed state in local storage | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350723 |
| ~frontend | Add feature discovery popover | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360111 |
| ~frontend  | Roll out feature flag | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/357219 |
| ~frontend | Store the pipeline editor popovers state in the database | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360635 |
| ~backend | Add messaging when files can't be fetched due to invalid CI configuration | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/360431 |

The frontend implementation is explained in detail in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/344940#note_790001555.

Some implementation notes for this step:
1. Drawer gets a list of included files which will open in a new tab (the file will open in file view in the repo).
1. The `.gitlab-ci.yml` would be highlighted as the currently open file (it won't be clickable as it's already open in the pipeline editor).
1. The other pipeline files will show an external link icon on hover.
1. The file names should be truncated after a certain number of characters, like we do in the [MRs file tree.](https://share.getcloudapp.com/NQu7J4v4) When a file name is truncated, we should show the full file name in a system tooltip on hover (same behavior as in the MRs file tree).
1. When project has a simple one-file pipeline, we'll show a notification inside the files section explaining that pipeline files will appear here.
1. When project doesn't have a pipeline file yet (for example, when you haven't committed the `.gitlab-ci.yml` yet), we won't show the file tree section and the file tree button. We will show the button and the file tree once you commit the file.
1. Tests filename are shown and that links are correct

title: Remove dynamic check for feature flags for Redis  increment counter API
description:
Related note https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/77866#note_814421104
Relate issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350055

# Summary

Remove dynamic check for feature flags from Redis increment_counter API.

# Details

We have [dynamic feature flags checked for this API](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/helpers.rb#L562) because of scalability and performance concerns.

This is not applicable for events tracked in the backend without using the API

We could remove the check, as we did not see until now any issues.

All Usage Data API requests are available for admin users and are behind the generic feature flag [`usage_data_api`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/usage_data.rb#L11)

This check is creating exceptions in how we check the feature flag usages see Related note https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/77866#note_814421104

## Testing

Update unit test

title: Class `code` breaks Usage statistics -> Preview Payload functionality
description:
### Summary Currently Preview Payload button doesn't work. It doesn't show payload when it received from the server It's quite likely caused by recent changes to `.code` class applied to the element. If I remove `.code` class, the element works. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/59a43d0b5dabdeab70685c4ad3d76c3b24ff5769/app/views/admin/application_settings/_usage.html.haml#L32-32 Also, if I rename tag from `pre` to, for example `p` it works as well. ### Steps to reproduce ![screencast_2022-01-20_16-53-39](/uploads/6b0f7554102e5ddb14e680eaf987f0ac/screencast_2022-01-20_16-53-39.gif) ### What is the current *bug* behavior? ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes

> > * Reduce your time to merge.
> >
> > [Learn more about merge request approval rules](#)
> >
> > \[ **Try for free** \]
> 
> 1. Title: Placed goal before feature name and introduced “your organization” as the target to contextualize the subsequent points.
> 1. “Require” instead of “Assign” to avoid confusion with “Assignees” and to clarify that they are not auto-assigned. Made it more concise and added “files changed” to indicate support for CODEOWNERS
> 1. Dropped the “organization” and “code” to make it more concise. Added “maintain standards”.
> 1. Made it more concise by removing the unnecessary “overall” and made it personal with “your”.
> 1. Learn more: used the feature's full name which is what users will see in the docs page.
> 1. Button: dropped the “it” which seemed unnecessary.
>
> @cnorris since `@aqualls` is off and this experiment is already live, would you mind taking a look at my suggestion above and improving it if necessary? Context: we're showing [this message](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346176#note_809621333) when users create/edit an MR to increase conversions to paid plans, using the “merge request approval rules” as the anchor.

epic.title: [ENG] Expose free users to required merge request approvals

title: Gitlab Pages token theft using service workers
description:
**[HackerOne report #1439552](https://hackerone.com/reports/1439552)** by `ehhthing` on 2022-01-02, assigned to @nmalcolm:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

#####  Summary  
It is possible to steal Gitlab Pages session tokens by intercepting requests to the `/auth` endpoint on a Pages site using service workers. 

#####  Attack Flow  
**Setup**  
1. The attacker creates a private Gitlab Pages site at the root of their user page `attacker.gitlab.io`, ensuring that the project is `private to collaborators` for Gitlab Pages visibility.   
2. The attacker invites the victim to collaborate to the project, thus giving them access to the private Pages site.  
3. The victim clicks on a link to `attacker.gitlab.io`, and a service worker is registered for the domain, passing through all requests back to the server except the `/auth` endpoint, which it intercepts.

**Bypassing the CSRF protection (OAuth2 `state` param)**  
4. A script on the website requests a valid session cookie and redirection URL from an attacker controlled website.  
5. The attacker controlled website sends its own request to `attacker.gitlab.io`, and retrieves a redirection URL and a session cookie.  
6. A script on the website redirects the victim to the redirection URL retrieved by the attacker, and the user authenticates (since the user is already logged in, this does not require any kind of interaction)

**Intercepting the OAuth2 Response**  
7. The OAuth2 service redirects the user back to `attacker.gitlab.io/auth` with the code and state, which is intercepted by the attacker's service worker and sent to the attacker controlled website.  
8. The attacker controlled website sends a request to the auth endpoint with the original session cookie and the intercepted code and state to obtain an authenticated session cookie.  
9. The attacker can use this cookie to access other GitLab Pages sites that the victim has access to.

#####  Steps to reproduce  
1. Create an attacker account and victim account. The victim account should have access to a private GitLab Pages site that the attacker does not have access to.  
2. Start the attacker controlled server (ensure that it is on a remote server with HTTPS)  
3. Import the Proof of Concept repository into the attacker's account, rename it to `{attacker username}.gitlab.io` and change the attacker server to the server deployed in step 2.  
4. Invite the victim to collaborate on the `{attacker username}.gitlab.io` project.  
5. While logged into the victim account, visit `{attacker username}.gitlab.io`.  
6. The attacker controlled server will output a valid `gitlab-pages` session cookie, which can be inserted into a browser or curl command (`curl -v --cookie '{cookie}' https://{victim username}.gitlab.io/{private Gitlab Pages project}`) to gain access to the private Gitlab Pages project on the victim's account.

#####  Examples

**Proof of Concept:**

Pages Project export: [2022-01-02_21-40-801_dotchinavideo_dotchinavideo.gi_export.tar.gz](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/c0bb7ff4-57b3-4a7d-a84c-d66f41ac006a/2022-01-02_21-40-801_dotchinavideo_dotchinavideo.gi_export.tar.gz)  
Pages Project on gitlab.com: https://gitlab.com/dotchinavideo/dotchinavideo.gitlab.io  
Attacker controlled server: [app.py](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/1586b70b-30fd-4a30-a0e1-df8c01c27f2d/app.py) (requires `flask` and `flask-cors` installed, outputs the stolen token to stdout)

#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?  
The current behavior is that `gitlab-pages` session cookies are not properly validated to ensure that the requested subdomain is the same as the subdomain to which the session cookie was issued for.

#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?  
The expected behavior is for each `gitlab-pages` session cookie be validated to prevent cross-subdomain usage.

#####  Relevant logs and/or screenshots  
[exploit.mp4](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/9c4cf962-eb14-4966-9871-a548efe954cc/exploit.mp4)

#####  Output of checks  
This bug happens on GitLab.com

######  Results of GitLab environment info  
This bug happens on GitLab.com

####  Impact

Once an attacker has a valid Pages session token, they are able to access every private Gitlab Pages site that the victim has access to.

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [app.py](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/1586b70b-30fd-4a30-a0e1-df8c01c27f2d/app.py)
* [exploit.mp4](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/9c4cf962-eb14-4966-9871-a548efe954cc/exploit.mp4)
* [2022-01-02_21-40-801_dotchinavideo_dotchinavideo.gi_export.tar.gz](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/c0bb7ff4-57b3-4a7d-a84c-d66f41ac006a/2022-01-02_21-40-801_dotchinavideo_dotchinavideo.gi_export.tar.gz)

## How To Reproduce

Please add [reproducibility information] to this section:

1.

title: Breaking change: Update API permissions for Package settings to Maintainer/Owner
description:
### Context

The GitLab Package stage offers a Package Registry, Container Registry, and Dependency Proxy to help you manage all of your dependencies using GitLab. Each of these product categories has a variety of settings that can be adjusted using the API. Currently these settings require Developer+ permissions.

### Problem to solve

Some of these settings like cleanup policies will permanently delete dependencies, which is quite a destructive action. After doing competitive research, most other companies limit these settings to Maintainer/Owner users. 

### Proposal

Update the permissions level of the GitLab API to require Maintainer/Owner level permissions to CRUD any Package stage-related settings. 

#### Settings

1. [x] [Mutation.updateNamespacePackageSettings](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html)
1. [x] [PackageSettings](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html#packagesettings)
1. [x] [DependencyProxySetting](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html#dependencyproxysetting)
1. [x] [DependencyProxyImageTtlGroupPolicy](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html#dependencyproxyimagettlgrouppolicy)
1. [x] [Mutation.updateDependencyProxySettings](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html#mutationupdatedependencyproxysettings)
1. [x] [ContainerExpirationPolicy](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html#containerexpirationpolicy)

#### Validation notes

:warning: When working on the Package Settings, it is crucial to validate all the related security issues get fixed. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/322055#note_862775425

epic.title: Breaking changes for the Package stage: Milestone 15.0

title: [FE] Change the expiring info alert into a danger alert

title: Deprecate option to update notes confidentiality via REST and GraphQL APIs
description:
Currently, it is possible to update notes confidentiality via GraphQL (see [`UpdateNote`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/graphql/mutations/notes/update/note.rb#L15)) and REST (see [`#update_note`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/helpers/notes_helpers.rb#L23)) endpoints, but it should be reverted.

Once a discussion is marked as confidential it should not be switched back to non-confidential (and vice-versa).

As the feature is behind a feature flag this should not be considered a breaking change. However, we can make it clear in documentation that this API endpoint has been deprecated for a period before removing the attribute entirely from the APIs.

### Proposal

- Deprecate `:confidential` argument in public endpoints

### Tasks

- [x] Deprecate the GraphQL endpoint(s) ([Guidance](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/#deprecation-and-removal-process))
- [x] Deprecate the REST API endpoint(s)
- [x] Create a follow up issue to remove mutable note confidentiality from APIs entirely and schedule for appropriate milestone https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/358734

In 15.3, you can now see the associated release when viewing a specific tag's information page. This allows you to easily know if a release has been created based on that specific tag.

### Problem to solve

The section "Release notes" can be used as a summary of the feature and is also required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated using the release post item generator:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator. title: Deleting last file leaves empty package in UI
description:
### :fire: Problem

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/345755, we created a background job that process package files that are marked as `pending_destruction`.

The problem is if _all_ package files are marked = the background job will remove all of them and leave the package object behind. That package object has no package files and can lead to a confusing ~UX :

![Screenshot_2022-01-19_at_09.16.17](/uploads/b2b9b8ee1fa3a109f262f4b54675ece6/Screenshot_2022-01-19_at_09.16.17.png)

I will categorize this as a ~UX ~"type::bug" 

### :fire_engine: Solution

The most logical thing to do here is to check the package object at the end of the cleanup job.

If the package is empty, we can safely remove it.

Ideally, we should implement this _when_ we introduce the first change that will mark package files as `pending_destruction`. This way, we will not have empty packages behind.

### :rainbow: UX solution

:art: See attached designs

| Before | After |
| ------ | ------ |
| Deleting last file leaves empty package in UI | Deleting last file removes package and returns user to package registry page |

### Implementation plan

- Before showing the delete file confirmation modal, if it is the last file being deleted then call the `deleteModal` function instead, can be handled here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/packages_and_registries/package_registry/pages/details.vue#L209-213

title: Use OWNER access level for personal project owners
description:
We give `MAINTAINER` access level to personal project owners:
```ruby
> project.personal?
=> true
> project.team.human_max_access(project.owner.id)
=> "Maintainer"
```

In comparison, for a project in group:
```ruby
> project.personal?
=> false
> project.team.human_max_access(user.id)
=> "Owner"
```

We currently have a workaround for this, so we end up with the expected behaviour: in `ProjectPolicy` we [disregard their access level](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v14.6.0-ee/app/policies/project_policy.rb#L9), and only check if they are `Project#owner`.

To simplify things, let's give owners the `OWNER` access level.

title: Phase out project Owner method
description:
In-depth analysis of Owner method usages:

`project.owner` method - it is a bit everywhere. In most specs it can probably be replaced by `first_owner` (whoever that is) but I'm loath to blanket replace in the code. 

In the specs, many of the usages are some permutation of `let(:user) { project.owner }` so these can probably be changed easily to `first_owner`.

### `spec`

- `spec/controllers` and `spec/graphql` :point_right: !78628 
- `spec/factories` :point_right: !78629
- `spec/features` :point_right: !78757 
- `spec/finders` :point_right: !78855 
- `spec/frontend_fixtures` :point_right: !78856 
- `spec/lib` :point_right: !78861
- `spec/policies` :point_right: !78860
- `spec/requests` :point_right: !79003
- `spec/services` :point_right: !78518
- the rest of the easy ones :point_right: !79079

### `ee/spec`

- A-F :point_right: !79183 
- G-L :point_right: !79184
- M-Z :point_right: !79185

Here are some places where it appears in the code that are a bit complex:

| Code location | Action | MR |
| ------------- | ------ | -- |
| [ee/app/views/projects/settings/subscriptions/_project.html.haml#L7](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/ee/app/views/projects/settings/subscriptions/_project.html.haml#L7) | `avatar_without_link` and the project owner name. Up to UX how they'd like to display this to handle multiple owners (a list of avatars up to x width?) | !78445 |
| [app/workers/container_expiration_policy_worker.rb#L60](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/app/workers/container_expiration_policy_worker.rb#L60) | Called by a worker invoked by a cron job. Not sure who the target user would be if there were multiple owners :thinking: perhaps if we can't use `nil`, the `first_owner` would be ok here | !78512 |
| [app/services/projects/create_service.rb#L92](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/app/services/projects/create_service.rb#L92) | Logs the project owner name after creation - so I think this can be `current_user` | !78511 |
| [app/workers/auto_devops/disable_worker.rb#L35](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/app/workers/auto_devops/disable_worker.rb#L35) | This adds recipients for a notification so we probably want to add all the owners of the project (would this also include inherited owners from the parent group(s)?) | !79078 |
| [app/models/issue.rb#L589](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/app/models/issue.rb#L589) | this is a performance improvement to the policy framework meant to sync with IssuePolicy. Suggest replacing `project.owner == user` check with `project.team.owner?(user)` | !78515 |
| [ee/app/services/ee/notification_service.rb#L124](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/ee/app/services/ee/notification_service.rb#L124) | Returns an array of a single owner so can be changed to `return project.owners` instead of `return [project.owner] unless group`. This line could also be removed altogether if the project membership lookup does what we want anyway | !79089 |
| [lib/gitlab/utils/override.rb#L76](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/lib/gitlab/utils/override.rb#L76) | This is a method owner (ie. reflection) and is unrelated. | n/a |
| [lib/gitlab/hook_data/project_builder.rb#L35](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/lib/gitlab/hook_data/project_builder.rb#L35) | This seems really tricky to change because the data structure expects a single owner :thinking: We could replace with `first_owner` or change the structure altogether | !79285 |
| [app/views/admin/projects/show.html.haml#L42](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/app/views/admin/projects/show.html.haml#42) and [app/views/admin/projects/show.html.haml#L50](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/app/views/admin/projects/show.html.haml#50) | change from a single owner display to an array of users, so from `= link_to @project.owner_name, [:admin, @project.owner]` to `- @project.owners each` with `= link_to owner.name, [:admin, owner]` or something. | !78974 | 

### Needs action?

| Code location | Action | MR |
| ------------- | ------ | -- |
| Access matcher [spec/support/matchers/access_matchers.rb](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/spec/support/matchers/access_matchers.rb#L27) | Role check on membership | No action needed |
| [spec/support/matchers/access_matchers_for_controller.rb](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/spec/support/matchers/access_matchers_for_controller.rb#L42) | Matchers for objects that respond to `owner` | Comment left  |
| [spec/support/helpers/access_matchers_helpers.rb](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/spec/support/helpers/access_matchers_helpers.rb#32) | Matchers for objects that respond to `owner` | Comment left |
| [lib/gem_extensions/active_record/disable_joins/associations/association_scope.rb](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/6baff2b4c62f5d827b35b5c9d7147ab5bea45a20/lib/gem_extensions/active_record/disable_joins/associations/association_scope.rb#L10) | Looks polymorphic, so `owner` looks like it refers to a reflective property | No action needed |

We could also do away with this method `project_owner_acting_as_maintainer` [app/finders/projects/members/effective_access_level_finder.rb](app/finders/projects/members/effective_access_level_finder.rb#L88-95) if we can backfill Project Owners that are missing them.

title: Review Elasticsearch 8.0 Breaking Changes for potential issues
description:
Anticipating the upcoming release of Elasticsearch 8.0 we will need to review the list of breaking changes and determine any testing that may be needed. 

https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/master/migrating-8.0.html#breaking-changes-8.0

Elasticsearch has not published a release date for 8.0.

- If it's a possible concern we should list it here. 
- We will take these issues and determine is we need to act on testing with the RC. 
- because Gitlab 14.8 is releasing on Feb 22nd, Our changes that will be needed for compatibility would be in 14.9. 
- We might determine the need to notify customers to not use Version 8.0 until Gitlab 14.x

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1cZdajOyLUhRnotS3synkUJeQgVacy8KvKtfz-RdHJHY/edit?usp=sharing

- [x] Compile the full list in Google Sheets
  - [Google Sheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1cZdajOyLUhRnotS3synkUJeQgVacy8KvKtfz-RdHJHY/edit?usp=sharing
) 
- [ ] Review the list removing anything that can be clearly omitted
- [ ] Break the items left into 3 groups 
- [ ] Add Notes for Each Item if it might be of concern 
- [ ] Create Issues for Items that might be of concern for deep-dives 
- [ ] Allocate time for the deep-dives
- [ ][ Add to Pipeline to test ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/80714)


#### Create issue for 
Need to change from `nGram` to `ngram` 
located in `Main Mapping Config.rb`
ref breaking change

**The nGram and edgeNGram tokenizer names have been removed.**
	
The nGram and edgeNGram tokenizer names haven been deprecated with 7.6 and are no longer
supported on new indices. Mappings for indices created after 7.6 will continue to work but
emit a deprecation warning. The tokenizer name should be changed to the fully equivalent
ngram or edge_ngram names for new indices and in index templates.
Impact
Use the ngram and edge_ngram tokenizers. Requests to create new indices
using the nGram and edgeNGram tokenizer names will return an error."

title: Can no longer assign a group to Merge Request Approvals rules
description:
### Summary I can no longer find and therefore add a group to a project Merge Request approval rule. ### Steps to reproduce Go to Settings -> General -> Merge Request Approval Click on Add approval Rule Enter Name and search for known group in the search box. None of my groups can be found. ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-18_at_2.13.12_PM](/uploads/1a380ac7efea62457d1a096a15d4ec37/Screen_Shot_2022-01-18_at_2.13.12_PM.png) HOWEVER, I can use the API to add this group correctly: `curl -s -f -X POST -H 'PRIVATE-TOKEN: ' --header 'Content-Type: application/json' --data '{"name": "approvals", "group_ids": ["11621528"], "approvals_required": 1}' https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/32550781/approval_rules` This adds my group correctly as shown below: ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-18_at_2.19.11_PM](/uploads/229882dd8e3ab1790861e962f99469a9/Screen_Shot_2022-01-18_at_2.19.11_PM.png) Opening up the RULE created via the api shows the group selected: ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-18_at_2.20.57_PM](/uploads/082612098e5a511a3ec8b8c0c6f26fa3/Screen_Shot_2022-01-18_at_2.20.57_PM.png) ### Example Project See above for example ### What is the current *bug* behavior? ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes

title: Registry phase 2 migration: Container repository state machine
description:
## Context

The context for this issue can be viewed in the epic https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7316 and the breakdown of work can be viewed in this comment https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7316#note_792633854.

## :robot: State Machine

We have many states/transitions to handle here. I think it would be beneficial to use the already included https://github.com/state-machines/state_machines-activerecord gem to manage this part.

Roughly speaking here, this is what we could have (code might be inaccurate):

```ruby
state_machine :migration_state, initial_state: :default do
  event :start_pre_import do
    transition default: :pre_importing
  end

  event :finish_pre_import do
    transition pre_importing: :pre_import_done
  end

  event :start_import do
    transition pre_import_done: :importing 
  end

  event :finish_import do
    transition importing: :done
  end

  event :already_migrated do
    transition default: :done
  end

  event :abort do
    transition %i[pre_importing importing] => :aborted
  end

  event :skip do
    transition %i[default pre_importing importing] => :skipped
  end

  event :retry_pre_import do
    transition aborted: :pre_importing
  end

  event :retry_import do
    transition aborted: :importing
  end

  before_transition any => :pre_importing do |container_repository| 
    container_repository.migration_pre_import_started_at = Time.zone.now
    container_repository.client.start_pre_import # this can make the transition fail
  end

  before_transition pre_importing: :pre_import_done do |container_repository| 
    container_repository.migration_pre_import_done_at = Time.zone.now
  end

  before_transition any => :importing do |container_repository| 
    container_repository.migration_import_started_at = Time.zone.now
    container_repository.client.start_import # this can make the transition fail
  end

  before_transition importing: :done do |container_repository| 
    container_repository.migration_import_done_at = Time.zone.now
  end

  before_transition any => :aborted do |container_repository|
    container_repository.migration_aborted_in_state = container_repository.migration_state
    container_repository.migration_retries_count += 1
  end

  before_transition any => %i[done aborted] do
    EnqueuerJob.enqueue # perform_async or perform_in depending on the speed FF
  end
end
```

This should upgrade the container repository with all the necessary scopes/methods to handle the evolution of the migration state.

I'm not sure if all these `before_transition` blocks are implementable like this. For example, can we do an http request during a `before_transition`? I left this to a side as an implementation detail.

title: Link to sentry failures when review-qa-* jobs fail
description:
### Objective

Shorten the time to recovery from a `review-qa-*` failure by bringing more information to the MR author. 

### Proposal

Add a link to Sentry failures for the Review App environment by using the review app environment release like https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlab-review-apps/?query=release%3A6095b501da7 or URL like https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlab-review-apps/?query=url%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fgitlab-review-require-ve-u92nn2.gitlab-review.app%2F%22 in a comment for relevant errors.

title: Geo: Revisit "Learn more" on the UI and remove redundant link
description:
## Context

It was suggested in the [UX weekly](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1fSRyTboySDpWPrQiiFIcIOhg09-9G54haIippIVtcCY/edit?usp=sharing), that it's better to avoid circular links point to a procedure that explains how to get to the page users' already on.

### Problems

- If users already stay on that page, providing another link is redundant.
- We get frequent feedback from users "UI clutter"

### Plan

- Go through the whole UI
- Remove some "Learn more" text to the doc if they are repetitive, or not necessary.

### Findings

<details><summary>Start (Empty) state</summary>

![Screenshot_2022-01-21_at_10.18.13](/uploads/5070bb5f8f177ec09742323b5a958299/Screenshot_2022-01-21_at_10.18.13.png)

| As-is | To-be idea |
| ------ | ------ |
| Learn more (subheading): `/help` docs | We could remove this link. Anyway, users will open up our documentation when they encountered problems. |
| Learn more button: Product help page | - |

</details>

<details><summary>Edit primary site</summary>

![Screenshot_2022-01-21_at_12.37.21](/uploads/c27f005400612394a0c4fb133d75089a/Screenshot_2022-01-21_at_12.37.21.png)

| As-is | To-be idea |
| ------ | ------ |
| Site name & Internal URL: [Docs link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/admin_area/geo_nodes.html#common-settings)  | Remove `Learn more` in help texts and put descriptions with subheadings |
| Tuning settings: [Docs link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/disaster_recovery/background_verification.html#repository-verification) | ✅ |

</details>

<details><summary>Edit secondary site</summary>

![Screenshot_2022-01-21_at_13.11.16](/uploads/3c1b25068c969dfbd7e491905ff63a97/Screenshot_2022-01-21_at_13.11.16.png)

| As-is | To-be idea |
| ------ | ------ |
| Site name & Internal URL: [Docs link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/admin_area/geo_nodes.html#common-settings)  | Remove `Learn more` in help texts and put descriptions with subheadings - [link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/admin_area/geo_nodes.html#secondary-site-settings) |
| Sync settings: [Docs link - selective sync](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/configuration.html#selective-synchronization) | 🟡 We could remove this from the subheading and move it below the selective sync field. |
| Object storage settings: [Docs link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/object_storage.html)  | ✅ |
| Tuning settings: [Docs link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/disaster_recovery/background_verification.html#repository-verification) | We could remove this and let users use the first link `secondary-site-settings`  |

</details>

<details><summary>Geo sites (after adding nodes)</summary>

![Screenshot_2022-01-24_at_16.24.52](/uploads/8239d995d9a46291cf31d0189ae8fea2/Screenshot_2022-01-24_at_16.24.52.png)

| As-is | To-be idea |
| ------ | ------ |
| Learn more (subheading): `/help` docs | :point_up: to the empty state |
| Status check: [Docs link - Repository verification](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/troubleshooting.html#check-the-health-of-the-secondary-node) | Probably we could leave it only on the secondary sites as the docs is also focusing on the secondary's status. |
| Verification information: [Docs link - Repository verification](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/disaster_recovery/background_verification.html#repository-verification) | ✅ |
| Replication status: [Docs link - Geo](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/#pausing-and-resuming-replication) | ✅ |
| Replication details: [Docs link - Data type](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/replication/datatypes.html#supported-geo-data-types) | We could remove this if we got merged this issue - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330508/ |
| Verification status: [Docs link - Repository verification](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/geo/disaster_recovery/background_verification.html#repository-verification) | Since we have verification information link, we could remove this. |

</details>

## Proposal

- [Figma spec 🔗](https://www.figma.com/file/6zDmExHBwBKaeil93vdlBz/Geo-(Moving-from-the-previous-board)?node-id=6%3A21)
- Design tabs :dancer: 

## Link

- [Helping users behavior - Pajamas](https://design.gitlab.com/usability/helping-users)

title: Move Secret Detection script logic into the analyzer
description:
### Description
Secret Detection is unlike the other analyzers in that it scans git history by inspecting the output of `git log -p ...` instead of analyzing whole files/projects. Determining what parts of a git history to scan is not a straight forward task. Currently, the vendored template uses this [script](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Jobs/Secret-Detection.gitlab-ci.yml#L32-45) to prepare the git repo and git ranges. 
# 
There are 4 scenarios we should cover to make sure if secrets do get pushed, they are caught immediately.

#### 1. Push events 
1 or more commits can be associated with a push event. Example of this would be if you are working on a feature branch and commit 5 changes to that branch _then_ push the branch. The Secret Detection job that gets triggered by the push event should scan _only_ those 5 commits. The commits associated with the MR can be retrieved by using `CI_COMMIT_BEFORE_SHA` and `CI_COMMIT_SHA`.

#### 2. Merge events
Merge events can have multiple push events associated with the event. This means retrieving the git of commits is not as straight forward and requires some form of `git log targetBranch..CIBranch` to determine the commit range.

#### 3. Full History Scans
Some users may want to scan the entire history of their repo on all branches. This is gitleaks default behavior and is supported by the `SECRET_DETECTION_HISTORIC_SCAN` variable.

#### 4. NoGit Scans
Users may want to scan the current state of their repo for secrets. This means treating repos as plain directories and scanning the contents of files for secrets. This is the current default behavior if no options are passed to the secret detection scanner.
# 

The git depth is set to 20 for shallow clones in Gitlab pipelines. Secret Detection overrides this and instead fetches the _entire history_ of `$CI_DEFAULT_BRANCH` and `$CI_COMMIT_REF_NAME`. This can cause some performance issues for large repos as fetching the full history of a repo is an expensive task. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/78321 introduces some changes that make `--depth` dynamic when fetching. This should give us full coverage so that all commits being pushed to Gitlab are scanned _and_ this should greatly reduce the time of secret detection jobs for large repos since we are only fetching what we need.

# 
@plafoucriere and @dsearles brought up some good points when reviewing https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/96577 saying we should move the `script` logic from the vendored template to the Secret Detection analyzer. I think this would be a worthwhile change for the following reasons:

1. Error handling: if an error pops up during a `git fetch` or `git log` we can handle the errors and log a useful message which would help with maintaining and debugging the analyzer. This would also help customers and support. 
2. All Secret Detection logic tied to one release operation. Instead of updating the Secret Detection analyzer AND vendored template, we would just have to update the analyzer. This would eliminate the dance between vendored template changes and analyzer releases that we are currently doing.

#### Proposal
Move the vendored template `script` logic _into_ the Secret Detection analyzer
